title: 113_s2901
content: The Act may be cited as the "10 Million Solar Roofs Act of 2014". Congress recognizes the potential for increasing solar electricity production in the US, leading to cost competitiveness with fossil fuels, reducing greenhouse gas emissions, enhancing national energy security, and promoting investments in renewable energy sources. Investments in solar energy create green jobs and economic benefits, with the US solar industry employing over 140,000 people in 2013, a 53% increase from 2010, and investing nearly $15 billion in the economy annually. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. This Act defines a "photovoltaic system" to include solar panels, roof support structures, inverters, integrated energy storage systems, and necessary hardware. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Energy. The Secretary will provide rebates for installing photovoltaic systems to reach a goal of 10,000,000 systems with 60,000 megawatts capacity over 10 years. Eligible recipients include homeowners, businesses, nonprofits, and government entities. The Secretary will provide rebates for installing photovoltaic systems in the United States. Eligible recipients must meet specific criteria determined by the Secretary. The rebate amount will be 15% of the initial capital costs or $10,000, whichever is lesser. Other entities in the United States may also qualify for rebates after public review and comment. The Secretary will provide rebates for installing photovoltaic systems in the United States, with the rebate amount being 15% of initial capital costs or $10,000. A report will be submitted to Congress after a 5-year period detailing the number of systems installed and steps to achieve the goal of 10,000,000 systems by 2024. This authority is in addition to other financial assistance for photovoltaic system installation. Authorization of appropriations is granted to carry out this Act.
